info.title: Getaround Owner API
info.description:
# Quick Start The Owner API uses the JSON format, and must be accessed over a [secure connection](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/HTTPS). Let’s assume that the access token provided by your account manager is “TOKEN”. Here’s how to get the list of ids of all your invoices from the first week of August with a shell script: ```bash query="end_date=2018-08-08T00%3A00%3A00%2B00%3A00&start_date=2018-08-01T00%3A00%3A00%2B00%3A00" curl -i "https://api-eu.staging-1.itsgoti.me/owner/v1/invoices?${query}" \ -H "Authorization: Bearer TOKEN" \ -H "Accept:application/json" \ -H "Content-Type:application/json" ``` And here’s how to get the invoice with the id 12345: ```bash curl -i "https://api-eu.staging-1.itsgoti.me/owner/v1/invoices/12345" \ -H "Authorization: Bearer TOKEN" \ -H "Accept: application/json" \ -H "Content-Type: application/json"" ``` See the [endpoints section](#tag/Invoices) of this guide for details about the response format. Dates in request params should follow the ISO 8601 standard. # Authentication All requests must be authenticated with a [bearer token header](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc6750#section-2.1). You token will be sent to you by your account manager. Unauthenticated requests will return a 401 status. # Pagination The page number and the number of items per page can be set with the “page” and “per_page” params. For example, this request will return the second page of invoices, and 50 invoices per page: `https://api-eu.staging-1.itsgoti.me/owner/v1/invoices?page=2&per_page=50` Both of these params are optional. The default page size is 30 items. The Getaround Owner API follows the [RFC 8288 convention](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc8288) of using the `Link` header to provide the `next` page URL. Please don't build the pagination URLs yourself. The `next` page will be missing when you are requesting the last available page. Here's an example response header from requesting the second page of invoices `https://api-eu.staging-1.itsgoti.me/owner/v1/invoices?page=2&per_page=50` ``` Link: ; rel="next" ``` # Throttling policy and Date range limitation We have throttling policy that prevents you to perform more than 100 requests per min from the same IP. Also, there is a limitation on the size of the range of dates given in params in some requests. All requests that need start_date and end_date, do not accept a range bigger than 30 days. # Webhooks Getaround can send webhook events that notify your application when certain events happen on your account. This is especially useful to follow the lifecycle of rentals, tracking for example bookings or cancellations. ### Setup To set up an endpoint, you need to define a route on your server for receiving events, and then ask Getaround to add this URL to your account. To acknowledge receipt of a event, your endpoint must: - Return a `2xx` HTTP status code. - Be a secure `https` endpoint with a valid SSL certificate. ### Testing Once Getaround has set up the endpoint, and it is properly configured as described above, a test `ping` event can be sent by clicking the button below:
You should receive the following JSON payload: ```json { "data": { "ping": "pong" }, "type": "ping", "occurred_at": "2019-04-18T08:30:05Z" } ``` ### Retries Webhook deliveries will be attempted for up to three days with an exponential back off. After that point the delivery will be abandoned. ### Verifying Signatures Getaround will also provide you with a secret token, which is used to create a hash signature with each payload. This hash signature is passed along with each request in the headers as `X-Drivy-Signature`. Suppose you have a basic server listening to webhooks that looks like this: ```ruby require 'sinatra' require 'json' post '/payload' do push = JSON.parse(params[:payload]) "I got some JSON: #{push.inspect}" end ``` The goal is to compute a hash using your secret token, and ensure that the hash from Getaround matches. Getaround uses an HMAC hexdigest to compute the hash, so you could change your server to look a little like this: ```ruby post '/payload' do request.body.rewind payload_body = request.body.read verify_signature(payload_body) push = JSON.parse(params[:payload]) "I got some JSON: #{push.inspect}" end def verify_signature(payload_body) signature = 'sha1=' + OpenSSL::HMAC.hexdigest(OpenSSL::Digest.new('sha1'), ENV['SECRET_TOKEN'], payload_body) return halt 500, "Signatures didn't match!" unless Rack::Utils.secure_compare(signature, request.env['HTTP_X_DRIVY_SIGNATURE']) end ``` Obviously, your language and server implementations may differ from this code. There are a couple of important things to point out, however: No matter which implementation you use, the hash signature starts with `sha1=`, using the key of your secret token and your payload body. Using a plain `==` operator is not advised. A method like secure_compare performs a "constant time" string comparison, which renders it safe from certain timing attacks against regular equality operators. ### Best Practices - **Acknowledge events immediately**. If your webhook script performs complex logic, or makes network calls, it’s possible that the script would time out before Getaround sees its complete execution. Ideally, your webhook handler code (acknowledging receipt of an event by returning a `2xx` status code) is separate of any other logic you do for that event. - **Handle duplicate events**. Webhook endpoints might occasionally receive the same event more than once. We advise you to guard against duplicated event receipts by making your event processing idempotent. One way of doing this is logging the events you’ve processed, and then not processing already-logged events. - **Do not expect events in order**. Getaround does not guarantee delivery of events in the order in which they are generated. Your endpoint should therefore handle this accordingly. We do provide an `occurred_at` timestamp for each event, though, to help reconcile ordering.

tags.name: Checkins
tags.description: Check-in - data from the start of the rental

tags.name: Checkouts
tags.description: Check-out - data from the end of the rental

get.summary: Find invoices associated to a rental
get.description: Find invoices associated to a rental

get.summary: Find a user by ID (Users are customers who rent one of your cars)
get.description: Find a user by ID (Users are customers who rent one of your cars)

get.summary: List of checkins that occurred between two dates
get.description: List of checkins that occurred between two dates

get.summary: List of checkouts that occurred between two dates
get.description: List of checkouts that occurred between two dates

get.summary: Find Unavailabilities related to a car between dates
get.description: Find Unavailabilities related to a car between dates

start_date.description: Start date and time of the unavailability in [ISO8601 format](https://www.iso.org/iso-8601-date-and-time-format.html)

end_date.description: End date and time of the unavailability in [ISO8601 format](https://www.iso.org/iso-8601-date-and-time-format.html)

car_id.description: Id of the car concerned by the unavailability

post.summary: New rental booked for one of your cars

requestBody.description: This event is triggered when a new rental booking has been created for one of your cars

200.description: Return a 200 status to indicate that the data was received successfully

post.summary: Canceled rental for one of your cars

requestBody.description: This event is triggered when a rental has been canceled for one of your cars

200.description: Return a 200 status to indicate that the data was received successfully

post.summary: Started rental for one of your car

requestBody.description: This event is triggered when a rental starts and the car has been unlocked

200.description: Return a 200 status to indicate that the data was received successfully

post.summary: Ended rental for one of your car

requestBody.description: This event is triggered when a rental ends and the car has been locked

200.description: Return a 200 status to indicate that the data was received successfully

post.summary: Rental time change for one of your car

requestBody.description: This event is triggered when the start or end time of a rental has been changed for one of your cars

200.description: Return a 200 status to indicate that the data was received successfully

post.summary: Unavailability created on one of your cars

requestBody.description: This event is triggered when a unavailability is created

200.description: Return a 200 status to indicate that the data was received successfully

post.summary: Unavailabilities deleted on one of your cars

requestBody.description: This event is triggered when unavailabilities are deleted

200.description: Return a 200 status to indicate that the data was received successfully

requestBody.description: This event is triggered when a user updates his profile information (You will only receive this event on users with a booked rental or a started rental).

200.description: Return a 200 status to indicate that the data was received successfully

4XX.description: The request can't be fulfilled due to an error on client-side, i.e. the request is invalid. The client should not repeat the request without modifications. The response body should contain a JSON error object. May be any HTTP status code specified in [RFC 7231](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc7231#section-6.6). HTTP status code 404 indicates path parameter is invalid.

errors.title: Invalid Attribute
errors.detail: First name must contain at least three characters.

5XX.description: The request can't be fulfilled due to an error at the back-end. The error is never the client’s fault and therefore it is reasonable for the client to retry the exact same request that triggered this response. The response body should contain a JSON error object. May be any HTTP status code specified in [RFC 7231](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc7231#section-6.6).

errors.title: Invalid Attribute
errors.detail: First name must contain at least three characters.

rental_id.description: The id of the rental, that the invoice is for

rental_start_date_and_time.description: The ISO8601 formatted planned start of the rental

rental_end_date_and_time.description: The ISO8601 formatted planned end of the rental

rental_price.description: The price of the rental, in cents (0.01€)

rental_checkin_date_and_time.description: The ISO8601 formatted real start of the rental

rental_checkout_date_and_time.description: The ISO8601 formatted real end of the rental

rental_distance.description: The distance driven during the rental

invoice_date.description: The date at which the invoice was emitted

total_price.description: The invoice amount, which is what you will receive (or which will be debited from your account if it is negative)

car_plate_number.description: The plate number of the car used for the rental

user_id.description: The id of the user who rented the car (also called the driver)

address.description: The driver’s address street number and street name

driver_license_number.description: The license number of the driver

driver_license_country.description: The country of the driver’s license

driver_compensation.description: **[charge]** Discount offered to the driver by the owner

drivy_cancellation_fee.description: **[charge]** Commercial gesture from Drivy platform to cover late cancellation fee

drivy_late_return_fee.description: **[charge]** Commercial gesture from Drivy platform to cover late return fee

drivy_mess_fee.description: **[charge]** Commercial gesture from Drivy platform to cover cleanliness fee

insurance_fee.description: **[charge]** Insurance premium for old price structure (applies to rentals booked before December 2018)

self_insurance_payment.description: **[charge]** Amount collected from the driver for insurance and given to self insured partner

additional_self_insurance_payment.description: **[charge]** Amount collected from the driver for additional insurance (CDW) and given to self insured partner

assistance_fee.description: **[charge]** Roadside assistance for old price structure (applies to rentals booked before December 2018)

drivy_breakdown_management_fee.description: **[charge]** Fee charged to the owner when a breakdown occurs

drivy_unfulfillment_fee.description: **[charge]** Fee charged to the owner for late cancellation

driver_gas_compensation.description: **[charge]** Fuel adjustment when a driver returns the vehicle with more or less fuel than at vehicle pick-up

driver_compensation_for_offsite_payment.description: **[charge]** Payment made on site between driver and owner (this should not happen for Connect rentals since the owner and driver don't meet)

drivy_gas_compensation.description: **[charge]** Commercial gesture from Drivy platform to cover fuel adjustment

exceptional_event_compensation.description: **[charge]** Commercial gesture from Drivy platform to cover exceptional event

damage_compensation.description: **[charge]** Payment for damage that occurred during a rental

other_compensation.description: **[charge]** Small financial adjustment that could happened in accounting

invoice_url.description: The temporary url (lifetime: 20min) to download the pdf of the tax invoice is generated each to time you call the endpoint. Also, the 'links' variable will not be present if there is no uploaded invoice yet. This could happen if the job to generate & upload the invoice is not done yet.

payments_index.description: An array of payments, ordered by completion date

amount.description: The amount of the payment, in cents (0.01€)

currency.description: The currency of the payment (ISO 4217 alphabetic code)

completed_at.description: The ISO8601 formatted payment completion date

invoices.description: An array of invoices paid by this payment

user_id.description: User id of the rental's driver

starts_at.description: Rental's started time in ISO8601 format

ends_at.description: Rental's ended time in ISO8601 format

booked_at.description: Rental's booked time in ISO8601 format

price.description: Price set by the owner (in cents 0.01€)

state.description: State of the vehicle can be a) active (only state where the vehicle can be booked by a user) b) inactive (temporary state when a vehicle is unavailable for rental) c) pending_approval (temporary state when a vehicle is under review for quality or other checks) and d) deleted (when a vehicle is permanently unavailable for rental)

display_address.description: Location where the vehicle is parked

phone_number.description: The phone number in international format

country.description: Address's country format ISO_3166-1_alpha-2 (ex: FR, ES, ...)

license_country.description: Driving licence country of issue format ISO_3166-1_alpha-2 (ex: FR, ES, ...)

id_doc_country.description: Identity document's country of issue format ISO_3166-1_alpha-2 (ex: FR, ES, ...)

checkin.description: A checkin is the event created when the user finished the pick up inspection.

rental_id.description: Rental's ID linked to this checkin

mileage.description: The vehicle’s mileage at checkin (in local units, eg: FR: km, GB: miles, ...)

fuel_level.description: The vehicle’s fuel level at checkin (in percentage)

checkout.description: A checkout is the event created when the user finished the drop off inspection.

rental_id.description: Rental's ID linked to this checkout

mileage.description: The vehicle’s mileage at checkout (in local units, eg: FR: km, GB: miles, ...)

fuel_level.description: The vehicle’s fuel level at checkout (in percentage)

distance_driven.description: The number of kilometers driven during this rental

starts_at.description: The ISO8601 formatted beginning of the unavailability's period

ends_at.description: The ISO8601 formatted ending of the unavailability's period

reason.description: The reason of the unavailability of the car.

occurred_at.description: The webhook event occurred at timestamp

starts_at.description: The ISO8601 formatted beginning of the unavailability's period

ends_at.description: The ISO8601 formatted ending of the unavailability's period

reason.description: The reason of the unavailability of the car.
